The mistake probably arose in the following manner. The law ol Pompey was criticized at the time as being retrospective. Thus Cato urged ‘let byegones be byegones¹.’ Later writers, wishing to explain ‘retrospective,' fixed the second consulship of Pompey in 55 as the limit². Appian first of all confused the second consulship with the first, and then proceeded to invent the story that the measure was aimed at Caesar, and that the friends of the latter protested against such an 'action ll so, this, in connexion with his other blunders, throws a curious light upon his methods as a historian.

The leverish anarchy which prevailed at Rome throughout this period was without doubt the most significant ol the many alarming symptoms which pointed to the speedy dissolution os the Republican system· The maintenance ol public order was entirely neglected by the state, or rather was not recognized as a matter which concerned the executive. The individual had totale the law into his own hands. A Roman built his house to stand a siege, and when he went about the streets was accompanied by an armed retinue. The magistrates, so far srom endeavouring to suppress disorder, were themselves the chiel offenders, the problem for the ‘practical politician’ of the day being how to hold the place of assembly against his rivals, while his hired gangs met in the name of the Roman people, and made binding throughout the civilized world any proposal, however mad or flagitiouS, which he cared to bring forward. The leading part in this camival of misrule naturally fell to the tribune, who, in virtue ol the sanctity ol his person, enjoyed the singular privilege ol being able to assault any other magistrate, while the injured person¹ was unable to retaliate.
